column1: 2015AGUFM.P33C2136M|2015|High Spatial Resolution <SUP>40</SUP>Ar/<SUP>39</SUP>Ar Geochronology of Impact Melt Breccias from Apollo 17 Boulders at Stations 2
column14: J. R.|AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts|||P33C|Several boulders located at the bases of the North and South Massifs were among the primary field targets of the Apollo 17 mission to the Taurus-Littrow Valley on the Moon [1]. Some boulders are polylithologic
column15: including Boulder 1 at Station 2 and the boulders at Stations 6 and 7. These boulders were the subjects of consortium studies [2
column16: 3] that included 40Ar/39Ar geochronology to determine the ages of distinct lithologies within each boulder [e.g.
column17: 4-6]. We report new 40Ar/39Ar data for the impact melt breccias 72255
column20: and 77135 obtained using the UV laser ablation microprobe (UVLAMP) methods of [7]. For 72255
column21: we obtained a preliminary isochron date ca. 3814 Ma from 22 melt analyses
column22: which is younger than published plateau dates (e.g.
column24: 8]). Fifteen melt analyses of 76315 yield a preliminary isochron date ca. 3850 Ma
column25: younger than the 3900 Â± 16 Ma date reported by [8]. Melt analyses of 77075 yield preliminary dates between ca. 3797-3584 Ma
column26: possibly reflecting partial loss of 40Ar. In this case
column27: the oldest date may provide a minimum age for the formation of melt in 77075. Finally
column28: the UVLAMP dates for the 77135 melt range from 3810-3361 Ma and corresponding Ca/K ratios range from ca. 100-6. Electron microprobe analyses of small (ca. 10s of microns wide) pockets of K-rich materials show that both K-rich glass and K-feldspar are present. The UVLAMP dates for 77135 likely reflect spatially variable 40Ar loss
column29: consistent with published step heating results [e.g.

column1: 1978LPSC....9..877M|1978|The Apollo 17 Station 7 boulder: Summary of study by the International Consortium.|Minkin
column6: E. C. T.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||877|A systematic interdisciplinary study of the Apollo 17 station 7 boulder
column7: from the foot of the North Massif at Taurus-Littrow
column8: is described. The astronauts observed four lithologies: a large white clast represented by 77215
column9: cut by dark dikelets (77075) and enclosed in blue-gray breccia (77115); the assemblage of these three rock types is in turn surrounded by green-gray breccia (77135). The history of the station 7 boulder
column10: as construed from the results of the consortium study

column1: 1977LPSC....8.2301N|1977|The history of the Apollo 17 Station 7 boulder.|Nakamura
column4: M.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|2||2301|Rb-Sr and Sm-Nd methods were used to determine the age of the dark dikelets 77075 cutting the 4.36 b.y. noritic breccia 77215 of the Station 7 boulder of Apollo 17. A regression line corresponding to an age of 4.07 plus or minus 0.09 b.y. is obtained with an Rb-87 decay constant of 1.41 x 10 to the -11th/yr and an initial Sr-87/Sr-86 ratio of approximately 0.69918. It is noted that the intrusion age of the dikelets provides the most reliable criterion for determining the age of the entire boulder
column6: the boulder is not an extension of 77115
column7: which formed more recently. Attention is given to a generalized lunar history during the first 600 m.y.|

column2: minor and trace element abundances in samples from the Apollo 17 station 7 boulder: Implications for the origin of early lunar crustal rocks|Winzer
column13: John A.|Earth and Planetary Science Letters|23|3|439|Apollo 17 station 7 boulder consortia samples were analyzed for major and minor elements by a combined semimicro atomic absorption spectrophotometric and colorimetric procedure. Lithophile trace element abundances were determined by stable isotope dilution mass spectrometry. Three matrix types samples (77135
column15: and 77075) were found to be KREEP-rich fragment-laden melts with analogues throughout the Apollo 17 landing site. Of the five clasts analyzed
column18: troctolite) is thought to be a cumulate; 77135

column1: 1974E&PSL..23..429B|1974|The dissection and consortium allocation of Apollo 17 lunar rocks from the boulder at station 7|Butler
column4: T. E.|Earth and Planetary Science Letters|23|3|429|The Apollo 17 astronauts removed four rocks samples to represent each of the lithologies they recognized in the boulder at station 7: sample 77215 from an off-white meter-sized block; sample 77075 from one of the thin dikes that cross the off-white block; 77115 from the blue-gray rock adjacent to the off-white block and apparently continuous with thin dikes that cross the block; sample 77135 of the tan-gray or green-gray vesicular rock adjacent to the blue-gray (77115) rock. A consortium of investigators has been organized
column5: under the leadership of E.C.T. Chao
column6: to study the samples. Each sample shows a number of lithologic types in terms of clasts (or xenoliths) and matrices. A table shows how subsamples have been allocated for consortium study. Maps and photographs show the relations between subsample locations and lithologies for the two more dissected samples
